Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Chronology and Paleoecology of late Quaternary Proboscidean Extinctions in the Great Lakes Region (USA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Collaborative Research: Chronology and Paleoecology of late Quaternary Proboscidean Extinctions in the Great Lakes Region (USA)

Chris Widga1, Stacey Lengyel1, Greg Hodgins2, Jeff Saunders1, J. Douglas Walker3

1. Landscape History Program, Illinois State Museum, Springfield, IL
2. University of Arizona-NSF AMS Facility, Tucson, AZ
3. Department of Geology, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS

The factors underlying the extinction of 35 genera of North American mammals during the terminal Pleistocene have incited lively debate for over a century. At issue is whether the primary driver of extinctions was human hunting or climate-related landscape changes, the impact of other proposed catastrophic processes on megafaunal populations, or any combination of the above. Unfortunately, ambiguity in the timing of regional proboscidean extinctions has complicated rigorous comparisons of actual extinction events to cultural and climatic timelines. This study will improve the late Quaternary chronology of proboscidean extinctions in the Great Lakes region through direct dating of ~80 mammoth and mastodont assemblages from the study area, a region where these extinctions appear particularly protracted. The project will also refine our understanding of regional evolution in proboscidean ecological niches by examining isotopic records of animal diet (ä13C), seasonality (ä18O), and mobility (87Sr/86Sr) in teeth and bones, as well as skeletal records of individual life histories (e.g., growth rate, pathology). These datasets will be used to define changes in the niche structure of Proboscidea during the last ~50 ka, and to subsequently examine the niche structure of terminal Pleistocene proboscideans in light of these long-term patterns. These parallel chronological and paleoecological studies will be used to elucidate factors underlying presumed changes in proboscidean ecological niches immediately prior to extinction, and to examine the relative importance of proposed extinction processes (e.g., human hunting, vegetation changes) in the disappearance of proboscideans from the Great Lakes region. Dated proboscidean remains, when combined with analyses of individual life histories, diet, and mobility patterns, will offer insight into the structure of terminal Pleistocene ecosystems of the Great Lakes region, including the relative importance of proposed extinction drivers. This project also has the potential to identify ecological thresholds that are important to maintaining the viability of modern large mammal populations when exposed to rapidly changing climate conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the population dynamics of mammoths and mastodons in the Midcontinent during the last 50,000 years with the over-arching goal of understanding how, why, and when these species went extinct. Our objectives were to 1) improve the late Quaternary chronology of extinctions in the Midcontinent through direct dating of mammoth and mastodon remains, 2) examine the diet, mobility-patterns, and inter-species dynamics of these taxa, 3) better define ecological niches of proboscideans during the late Glacial, and 4) better understand the evolution of these niches as mammoths and mastodons approached extinction.

To this end, we inventoried collections from 48 museums in 8 states and 1 Canadian province, acquiring >100 radiocarbon dates on proboscidean remains.  The resulting chronology allowed us to examine changes in proboscidean populations as related to corresponding climate and cultural changes. Mammoths were the dominant proboscidean on the landscape during the last glacial maximum (LGM) while mastodons were dominant during the warmer, wetter period after the LGM. The broad geographic distribution of late mastodons and the widespread presence of multi-animal death sites in the region in the last few centuries before extinction suggest very large mastodon populations in the region at that time. The virtual absence of carnivore modification on bones from post-LGM mammoths and mastodons was an unexpected pattern. This, combined with pre-LGM terminal dates on midwestern large carnivores (e.g., Saber-cats and dire wolves), suggest that late proboscidean populations were minimally impacted by large predators. At an ecosystem scale, late mammoth and mastodon populations would have suffered from high juvenile recruitment rates with minimal pressure from predators which resulted in boom-bust cycling of proboscidean populations and cascading effects on regional ecosystems in the centuries leading up to extinction.

We also developed a new technique for acquiring stable isotope samples from mammoth tooth enamel. Previously, high-resolution sampling techniques were relatively destructive and required large sample sizes. Our method samples tooth enamel in situ, so damage to the specimen is limited. These samples can be analyzed for multiple stable isotopes to construct seasonally resolved records of animal diet and mobility. Preliminary results suggest midwestern mammoths did not engage in season migrations, but may have moved significant distances (>200 km) over the course of a lifetime. 

Public outreach was a critical component of the project. We created a series of online and collaborative projects to engage adult citizen scientists and K-14 students. Online resources included a dynamic web portal to research on the Ice Age Midwest (iceage.musuem.state.il.us), which included an extensive bestiary of Pleistocene mammals. We also collaborated with educators at the Milwaukee Public Museum and Waubonsee Community College (Sugar Grove, IL) to build paleontological outreach modules targeted to middle and high school classrooms (grades 4-14). Research results were communicated through social media, blog posts, and a temporary exhibit in the Illinois State Museum on Ice Age extinctions.
